Policies relating to the allowances paid to employers whose employees are obliged to reduce the number of hours worked were updated for the period 28 January to 28 February 22, providing:     - 36% of the employee's previous gross salary within the limit of 4.5 SMIC with a floor of â¬7.53    - 70% of the employee's previous gross remuneration (i.e. approximately 84% of the net salary), within the limit of a remuneration of 4.5 SMIC, with a floor of â¬8.37 per hour, regardless of the company's workforce  -- in establishments open to the public and closed by administrative decision to combat the spread of the covid19 epidemic  --in establishments located in a reconfined territory when they suffer a 60% loss of turnover either in relation to the turnover recorded during the month preceding the implementation of the reconfinement, or in relation to the turnover recorded for the same month in 2019.  -- for employers belonging to so-called protected sectors (S1, S1 Bis) and which suffer a decrease in turnover of at least 65 % compared to the turnover recorded for the same month in 2020 or 2019, in respect of the turnover achieved over the previous six months compared to the same period in 2019, compared to the average monthly turnover achieved in 2019 or, for companies created after 30 June 2020, in relation to the average monthly turnover achieved between the date of creation of the company and 30 june 2021 (before 1er December 2021, this drop in turnover had to be at least 80%) or subject to health restrictions. These companies can benefit from the partial activity scheme without any remaining expenses. The derogation of partial activity without remaining at the expense of these employers is renewed.    - https://web.archive.org/web/20220211172553/https://www.economie.gouv.fr/covid19-soutien-entreprises/dispositif-de-chomage-partiel    There are no changes to the policies supporting the self-employed - https://web.archive.org/web/20220211172612/https://www.economie.gouv.fr/covid19-soutien-entreprises/reponses-gouvernement-difficultes-independants

PCR and antigen tests are widely available, per the US Embassy in France:     - Antigen test results are available within 24 hours, often in less than one hour. PCR test results may take up to 48 hours.   - Numerous pharmacies offer rapid antigen tests on a walk-in basis. To locate pharmacies open after-hours, weekends, or holidays in Paris and outskirts visit https://web.archive.org/web/20220206184330/https://monpharmacien-idf.fr/?. To find late-night or emergency pharmacies anywhere in France, call 112 (European emergency number, available free of charge, 24/7).  - PCR testing is available?at many?laboratories and testing centers, usually by appointment â including the testing centers at?Parisâ airports.   - Antigen tests cost 25 Euros, payable in advance.?PCR tests cost 43.89 Euros. As of October 15 [2021], free COVID tests?at public testing centers?for French residents?are no longer available, with an exception for fully vaccinated residents or residents with a prescription.?Private testing centers, including pharmacies, may charge. COVID test results can be obtained on paper, or via email or SMS message.?     - https://web.archive.org/web/20220205235318/https://fr.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/    Government policy is described at https://web.archive.org/web/20220205235520/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus/tests-et-depistage

No change in policy, vaccination is universally available to people aged 5 and over.     Vaccination boosters are available to all people aged 18 and over from three months after the last injection or infection with Covid-19.    People aged 80 and over are eligible for home vaccination visits.     The Pfizer/BioNTech, Moderna, AstraZeneca/Vaxzevria/Covishield and Johnson & Johnson vaccines are authorised for use in France.     https://web.archive.org/web/20220109103311/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus/vaccins

Vaccination is universally available to people aged 5 and over, with one parent's permission required for children aged between 5 and 11.     Vaccination boosters are available to all people aged 12 and over from three months after the last injection or infection with Covid-19.    People aged 80 and over are eligible for home vaccination visits.     The Pfizer/BioNTech, Moderna, AstraZeneca/Vaxzevria/Covishield and Johnson & Johnson vaccines are authorised for use in France.     Vaccination is mandatory for all those who work in contact with frail people. Thus, since September 15, 2021, the following must be vaccinated:    - all staff (including administrative staff) of health institutions, medico-social institutions (EHPAD, USLD, autonomous residences, disability structures with or without accommodation and including non-medicalized), social institutions attached to a health institution (LHSS, LAM, CSAPA, CAARUD, CLAT, CEGGID);  - home helpers working with people affecting APA or PCH, in home services or as employees of individual employers;  - staff of medical transport companies (including taxis under agreement);  - all professions in Book IV of the CSP, whether or not under agreement, and professions for the use of titles, as well as their employees (e.g. medical secretaries, dental assistants);  - all health students;  - SDIS-Firefighters (professionals and volunteers);  - occupational health service personnel.  - Persons justifying a contraindication to vaccination are exempt from the vaccination obligation.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220206174049/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus/vaccins

England's Plan B measures are to end from Thursday 27 January. Covid passports dropped meaning all businesses are open, without any requirement to present a pass to get in. Mandatory Covid passports for entering nightclubs and large events would end, though organisations could choose to use the NHS Covid pass if they wished. People would no longer be advised to work from home and should discuss their return to offices with employers  Face masks will no longer be mandated, though people are still advised to wear coverings in enclosed or crowded spaces and when meeting strangers.    Covid passes still required in other devolved nations for access to some businesses so coding remains at a 2, but now Targeted not General    http://web.archive.org/web/20220121121233/https://www.bbc.com/news/uk-60047438

In Northern Ireland 'No more than 30 people can meet in a private home and stay overnight. Regulations remain in place that prevent gatherings/ parties of more than 30 people in domestic settings.'    https://archive.vn/rXYXV

Northern Ireland- recommendations remain in place    Travel  You should avoid visiting places where there is a chance that large numbers of people will gather and crowds will form.  If you go somewhere and there are crowds which will make social distancing difficult, consider going somewhere else instead.  When travelling you should walk, cycle or use private transport, shared only with members of your household where possible.  If possible, you should avoid car sharing with people from outside of your household. If you are car sharing, as well as wearing a face covering, good ventilation in the car is vitally important - particularly by keeping a window open.    https://archive.vn/rXYXV

Changes to be introduced 11 February for fully vaccinated travellers    Mr Speaker, from 4am on the 11th February, and in time for the half-term break, eligible fully vaccinated passengers arriving in the UK will no longer have to take a post-arrival, lateral flow test.    Today I can announce that passengers who do not qualify as fully vaccinated will no longer be required to do a day 8 test after arrival or, indeed, to self-isolate. They will still need to fill out a passenger locator form to demonstrate proof of a negative COVID test taken 2 days before travel, and they must also take a post-arrival PCR test.      https://archive.vn/FNxIc

Public and private schools in Georgia resumed in-person studies following winter holidays on January 17.  http://web.archive.org/web/20220130201314/https://agenda.ge/en/news/2022/211  Facemask use mandatory for all students.  http://web.archive.org/web/20220130173058/https://stopcov.gov.ge/en/page/restrictions-list

Public institutions are instructed to move their staff onto the remote format of work to the maximum extent possible and similar recommendation is given by the Council to employers in the private sector.  In line with a decision made by the Coordination Council, citizens of Georgia will be allowed to enter the following facilities with a Green Passport from December 1, 2021: indoor or outdoor eateries, restaurants, cafes and bars; cinemas, theatres, operas, museums, concert halls, entertainment centers, casinos and gambling centers; spas, fitness centers, hotels and cable lifts of ski resorts. The referred requirement will apply to visitors of the listed facilities. As for the entertainment centers for children, Green Passport will be required from citizens aged 18 and older. An individual will have a green status, if s/he is vaccinated, has a PCR test valid for 72 hours or antigen test valid for 24 hours or has been infected with a novel coronavirus. Night clubs remain banned both outdoors and indoors.  http://web.archive.org/web/20220130173058/https://stopcov.gov.ge/en/page/restrictions-list

Restriction remains valid on holding the wide-scale entertainment and such social events, as wedding parties, banquets, jubilees of various types and similar. Eateries and ritual venues of miscellaneous types will be sanctioned with 10 000 GEL for hosting such events but will be sealed if found in breach of the regulation for the second time. Night clubs remain banned both outdoors and indoors.  Any type of entertainment activities, arts and culture events (except for stage performances and cinema), festivals are going to be fully banned. The referred restriction does not apply to concerts to be held at the premises of hotels. As for sports tournaments of various types, they may be held without spectators. Nevertheless, every participant should be vaccinated (14 days should be lapsed from the second dose) or have a PCR test result obtained in the past 72 hours or a negative result of an antigen test obtained in the past 24 hours.  http://web.archive.org/web/20220130173058/https://stopcov.gov.ge/en/page/restrictions-list

No limit is listed so it is assumed there was no change. Border crossing is currently permitted to citizens of EU member states and 40 countries   in addition, as well as to individuals with a permission of residence. They need to present the following at the border crossing: document evidencing a full cycle of vaccination and a negative result of PCR test obtained in the past 72 hours, or alternatively present only a negative PCR test result obtained 72 hours prior to the visit to Georgia and get a repeated PCR test on the 3rd day of their stay in Georgia at their own expense.  When entering the country, foreign nationals who have had COVID-19 and are vaccinated with one dose, will be subject to the same regulation as applicable to individuals vaccinated with both doses.  Georgian citizens vaccinated in Georgia and entering the country through land borders are exempt from mandatory PCR testing.  http://web.archive.org/web/20220130173058/https://stopcov.gov.ge/en/page/restrictions-list  Mandatory 14-day quarantine, followed by a PCR test is imposed on anyone who has been in South Africa, Botswana, Zimbabwe, Namibia, Lesotho, Eswatini, Mozambique or Malawi in the previous 14-day period.  http://web.archive.org/web/20220130181211/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/georgia/entry-requirements

no policy change     Unless all passengers are members of the same family, a maximum of 3 persons are permitted to travel in a taxi or other private vehicle with up to 7 seats, or 4 persons in a private vehicle with up to 9 seats;  Cross-regional travel is allowed for mainland Greece and the islands of Lefkada, Evia and Salamina (use of self-tests ahead of travel is strongly recommended but is not mandatory).  Cross-regional travel to the rest of the islands is permitted but only with either:    proof of vaccination and 14 days since second dose (see Demonstrating your COVID-19 vaccination status), or  a negative result from a PCR test carried out up to 72 hours prior to travel; or  a negative result from a rapid test or self-test conducted up to 24 hours before travel; or  a self-test declaration signed less than 24 hours before travel; or  documentary proof of having recovered from Covid-19 (at least 2 months since infection, and no more than 9 months)  Travel in Greece  Travel within Greece between Regional Units is permitted subject to adherence to public health measures as outlined above. You must wear a mask at all times on all public transport.    If you are travelling via ferry, you will need to complete a health questionnaire and hand it to the ferry operator before boarding. The necessary forms will be provided by the operator: you should contact them directly if you need further information. Temperature checks may also be carried out before boarding.    If you are travelling by internal (domestic) flights, specific measures relating to check-in, baggage allowances and other details are in place to reduce the spread of coronavirus. You should check with your operator directly for further detail.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210802101710/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/greece/coronavirus

All those travelling to Greece (aged 5 or above) must show proof of a professionally administered negative rapid COVID-19 test taken no more than 24 hours before arrival or proof of a professionally administered negative PCR test taken no more than 72 hours before arrival.     The measure affects all arrivals, regardless of vaccination status or country of departure. The only exception is for arrivals who have spent less than 48 hours in a country prior to arriving in Greece.                                              Random antigen testing on arrival applies to every arrival to Greece, regardless of the certificate in their possession. If you are selected, please keep in mind that the screening is mandatory and in case of refusal, authorities reserve the right to refuse entry into the country.    If you are selected for a test and test positive, you will be subject to mandatory quarantine, for which you may be required by the Greek authorities to move to a designated quarantine facility.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220110161137/https://www.dfa.ie/travel/travel-advice/a-z-list-of-countries/greece/

Guidelines for primary schools, day care institutions and recreational activities:  -In the case of infection at schools and institutions etc., it will most often be other contacts that are of concern.  -Children, who are other contacts to an infected person (child or employee) in a day-care nursery etc., in school (including boarding schools and private schools) or in connection with recreational activities, must follow the recommendations for other contacts. Learn more in the section If you have been together with an infected person/been exposed to infection but are not a close contact.  -However, roommates at boarding schools etc., must follow the guidelines for close contacts.  *updated guidelines since 12 Jan 2022  https://web.archive.org/web/20220117002207/https://corona.nun.gl/en/at-the-workplace/guidelines-for-primary-schools-day-care-and-after-school-activities/

Important information for businesses:  -Naalakkersuisut might introduce restrictions that affect the workplace and businesses in general. Youâll find the latest official announcement here.  -Youâll find relevante posters here. Please note that the posters might be in Danish.  -Youâll find relevante guides and links here. Please note that the guides might be in Danish.  -Workplaces, educational institutions, etc. should clearly mark entrances with signs stating that access is prohibited for persons with COVID-19 symptoms and should have clear procedures in place for the handling of personnel, students, visitors etc. with COVID-19 symptoms, including how working at home/studying at home can be organised.  *updated since 26Jan2022  https://web.archive.org/web/20220117012750/https://corona.nun.gl/en/at-the-workplace/suliffeqarfimmi-malittarisassat-2-3/

In Greenland, there is a requirement that people aged 15 and older must be fully vaccinated if they want access to premises to which the public has access. Previously, a negative PCR test also gave access to such premises, but that is no longer possible.  -You must be fully vaccinated against COVID-19  -You are only allowed access to the following places if you are fully vaccinated against COVID-19:  1) Restaurants, cafes, pubs, discos and similar establishments.  2) Cultural institutions, including culture centres, cinemas, museums, exhibition halls, etc.  3) Community centres and similar establishments.  4) Libraries.  5) Indoor sports facilities, including sports colleges and sports halls, swimming pools, gyms, football pitches, etc.  6) Hairdressers, massage parlours, beauty clinics and similar establishments.  When are you fully vaccinated?  -People who have completed a full vaccination programme, for example two doses of Pfizer or Moderna vaccine or one dose of Johnson&Johnson vaccine, are considered fully vaccinated. There is currently no upper limit as to how long a person is considered fully vaccinated. This means that for the time being there is no requirement to get the booster vaccination to be considered fully vaccinated.  -If you have previously been infected with COVID-19 and can present documentation of a positive PCR test result which is between 14 days and 12 weeks old, you are covered by the same rules as if you were fully vaccinated.  *updated on 26Jan2022  https://web.archive.org/web/20211228235327/https://corona.nun.gl/en/corona-passport-digital-eu-covid-certificate/vaccination-as-a-requirement-for-access/

Corona passport (digital EU COVID certificate)  -People in Greenland who have been vaccinated can get a corona passport.  -You can use a corona passport e.g. if you are travelling abroad and you need to document that you have been vaccinated against COVID-19. In some countries, you must show your corona passport or documentation of previous infection upon arrival.  https://archive.vn/lWkU1    Area restrictions  -There is no longer an inventory of cities and settlements with spread of infection from unknown sources. Restrictions regarding use of face masks and maximum occupancy of establishments apply to the entire country with exception of Ittoqqortoormiit and Tasiilaq, as well as the settlements Kulusuk, Isortoq, Kuummiut, Sermiligaaq and Tiniteqilaaq. The executive order is published on Naalakkersuisutâs announcement portal. Current restrictions are also explained in detail on the various pages at corona.nun.gl  https://archive.vn/Bp0OH    *updated guidelines and restrictions since 04 Feb 2022

Pay special attention to hygiene and cleaning  -Wear a CE-marked face mask if in exceptional cases, you have to break isolation for a short period of time.  -Remember that you must not use public transport.  https://web.archive.org/web/20220117014737/https://corona.nun.gl/en/infection-and-symptoms/if-you-have-symptoms/

In public transport passengers can be helped to keep their distance and reduce the number of contacts by e.g. limiting mobility, limiting standing passengers by using booked seating, reducing the possibility of passengers moving around and between each other, etc.  *Infection Prevention Advice  https://web.archive.org/web/20211206130814/https://corona.nun.gl/en/prevention/infection-prevention-advice/

Stay at home and isolate if you have COVID-19 symptoms or have tested positive.  If you have COVID-19 symptoms or are infected with the coronavirus you should isolate.  To isolate means:  -You must stay at home and not meet with other people who you do not live with.  -You must avoid contact with the people you live with.  -You must pay special attention to good hygiene and cleaning.  If you have tested positive for the coronavirus and it is not possible to keep to a sufficient distance from others in your household, the municipality may possibly provide you with voluntary isolation accommodation outside the home. For example, if your home is very small or you share your household with people who are at an increased risk of serious illness from COVID-19. Call the coronavirus hotline and learn about your options.  https://web.archive.org/web/20211206130814/https://corona.nun.gl/en/prevention/infection-prevention-advice/

Conditions for entry into Greenland:  -To be permitted to enter Greenland, you must either be fully vaccinated or a resident of Greenland or you are relocating to Greenland.    -In regard to entering Greenland, you are considered fully vaccinated 14 days after you have completed a full vaccination programme, e.g. two doses of Pfizer or Moderna or one dose of Johnson&Johnson. There is currently no upper limit as to how long a person is considered fully vaccinated. This means that for the time being there is no requirement to get the booster vaccination to be considered fully vaccinated.    When you intend to travel to Greenland, you must remember to do the following:  -You must have a negative COVID-19 PCR test from a Nordic country (Denmark, Sweden, Norway, Finland, Iceland, Faroe Islands), UK, Liechtenstein, Switzerland, or a country in EU that is maximum 48 hours old from the time of departure and have valid documentation showing this.  -Bring a face mask for the journey and wear it during the journey, on the plane and in the airport, and also during transport to your place of residence. This rule applies to everyone at 12 years old or older.  https://web.archive.org/web/20211220215011/https://corona.nun.gl/en/travel/conditions-for-entry-into-greenland/

Conditions for entry into Greenland:  -From January 26 2022 and onwards, there is no longer a requirement to present a negative PCR test upon entry into Greenland.  -To be permitted to enter Greenland, you must either be fully vaccinated or a resident of Greenland or you are relocating to Greenland.  -In regard to entering Greenland, you are considered fully vaccinated immediately after you have completed a full vaccination programme, e.g. two doses of Pfizer or Moderna or one dose of Johnson&Johnson. There is currently no upper limit as to how long a person is considered fully vaccinated. This means that for the time being there is no requirement to get the booster vaccination to be considered fully vaccinated.    When you intend to travel to Greenland, you must remember to do the following:  -Documentation of your vaccine status  -Certificate of residence or something else that documents that you are a resident of Greenland (applies to unvaccinated citizens who are living in Greenland)  -Bring a face mask for the journey and wear it during the journey, on the plane and in the airport, and also during transport to your place of residence. -This rule applies to everyone at 12 years old or older.  -Special rules apply if you have previously been infected with COVID-19 within the last 12 weeks. Read more in the section âPreviously infected with COVID-19â here.  https://web.archive.org/web/20220129073108/https://corona.nun.gl/en/travel/conditions-for-entry-into-greenland/

Conditions for entry into Greenland  -There is no longer a requirement to present a negative PCR test upon entry into Greenland.  -To be permitted to enter Greenland, you must either be fully vaccinated, a resident in Greenland or relocating to Greenland.    You are considered fully vaccinated immediately after you have completed a full vaccination programme, e.g. two doses of Pfizer or Moderna or one dose of Johnson&Johnson. There is currently no upper limit as to how long a person is considered fully vaccinated. There is no requirement for a booster vaccine to be considered fully vaccinated.    When you intend to travel to Greenland, you must remember to do the following:  -If you are not a resident in Greenland, you must bring documentation that you are fully vaccinated or a positive PCR test result which, at the time of departure, is at least 14 days and at most 12 weeks old  -If you are a resident in Greenland, you must bring a certificate of residence or something else that documents your residency  -If you are about to move to Greenland, you must show a lease, employment contract or something else that documents your move  -Bring a face mask for the journey and wear it during the journey, on the plane and in the airport, and also during transport to your place of residence. This rule applies to everyone at 12 years and older.  *updated policy  https://archive.vn/uwO8J

*Updated guidelines  If you receive a SMS with a positive test result, you should:   -Isolate   -Inform your close contacts  -Wait for a call from the health department / corona secretariat  This applies regardless of whether you are fully vaccinated or not, and whether you have symptoms or not.  https://web.archive.org/web/20220117024228/https://corona.nun.gl/en/infection-and-symptoms/if-you-test-positive/

Test result:  -If your test is positive, it means you are infected with the coronavirus.  -If your COVID-19 test is positive, you will receive your test result via SMS. You are responsible for contacting your close contacts. Read more about the definition of a close contact.  -If you have taken an antigen test (home test) which shows a positive result, you should consider yourself infected with COVID-19. You must follow the same guidelines, but you will not be contacted by the healthcare system.  https://web.archive.org/web/20211206141614/https://corona.nun.gl/en/infection-and-symptoms/if-you-test-positive/

Use of face masks and visors:  -Face masks can be used as a supplement for preventing the spread of infection in situations where it is difficult to keep to distance. It is important that you continue to follow the advice relating to keeping a distance and good hygiene even when you wear a face mask.    In Greenland, you must wear a face mask in the following situations:  -All individuals aged 12 years or older on domestic or international flights (face masks must be worn to the quarantine location/end destination).  -If you have been infected or risk of being infected with COVID-19 and in exceptional circumstances must move outside, e.g. because you need to get tested.  https://web.archive.org/web/20220129080932/https://corona.nun.gl/en/prevention/use-of-face-masks-and-visors/

https://web.archive.org/web/20220109221614/https://www.koronavirus.hr/sto-moram-znati/o-skolovanju/13    Schools and colleges are adapting to the situation on a daily basis, and in order to provide education to all students in educational institutions, a hybrid model of education has been introduced - some have continued classroom teaching and some have introduced online teaching to prevent the spread of coronavirus. The new condition is also the physical distance that everyone must adhere to, so in educational institutions it is precisely determined what the distance between the tables must be, when the masks must be worn and how long the school lesson or lecture will last.

In order to adapt as much as possible to the new conditions, employers are advised to organize, wherever possible, work from home or work in shifts, in order to avoid interference by workers. For the protection of one's own, but also the health of others, it is recommended that all business trips be postponed and that meetings be held online. Jobs related to the health care system also have specially prescribed measures that employees must adhere to so that the system itself is not overloaded. All recommendations for employees and employers in trade, catering facilities, measures for drivers in road freight transport or employees in the state administration, can be found here.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211112163018/https://www.koronavirus.hr/sto-moram-znati/o-poslu/46

Restrictions for Individuals and Businesses  Businesses and individuals may be restricted due to the epidemiological measures based on your location in Croatia.    As of January 10, 2022, the Government of Croatia is imposing a range of epidemiological measures:    Indoor public gatherings are limited to 25 people.  Outdoor public gatherings are limited to no more than 50 people.  Outdoor public gatherings where everyone has EU digital certificates are limited to 200.  Private ceremonies will be limited to 20. Exception: private ceremonies in which everyone has a covid certificate will be limited to 50 people.  Sporting events and competitions: Indoor sports facilities may operate with up to 20 percent of spectator seating occupied. Outdoor events may operate with up to 40 percent of spectator seating occupied.  Catering / Dining establishments will be under more robust and compliance checks.  Individual counties and cities may have additional measures. Please visit?the?Croatian Governmentâs COVID-19 website?for additional information.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220125001728/https://hr.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

Professional artistic performances, cultural programs and events attended only by persons (visitors, performers and staff) holding an EU digital COVID certificate of vaccination, testing and / or recovery from COVID-19 are exempt from all restrictions of this recommendation - including the obligation to wear masks, physical distances, number of persons present, etc. Also, if all contractors have an EU digital COVID certificate, they are exempt from all anti-epidemic measures.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220129104111/https://www.koronavirus.hr/sto-moram-znati/o-svakodnevnom-zivotu/preporuke-za-sprjecavanje-zaraze-covid-19-tijekom-odrzavanja-profesionalnih-umjetnickih-izvedbi-kulturnih-programa-i-manifestacija/740

Pursuant to the Decision passengers (regardless of their citizenship) who arrive from the Republic of South Africa, Botswana, the Kingdom of Eswatini, Lesotho, Namibia, Zimbabwe and Republic of Mozambique or who stayed in those countries in the last 14 days are not allowed to enter the Republic of Croatia.  https://web.archive.org/web/20220109223019/https://mup.gov.hr/uzg-covid/english/286212

Entry rules in response to coronavirus  Entry to Croatia  To be allowed entry into Croatia, all travellers from the UK must present one of the following documents on arrival:    proof of a vaccination, not older than 365 days, or;  a negative COVID-19 antigen not older than 48 hours, or;  a negative PCR test result not older than 72 hours, or;  a doctorâs certificate of recovery from COVID-19. (See âDemonstrating your COVID-19 statusâ).  Children under 12 and accompanied by a parent or guardian are exempt from these requirements if the parent or guardian has one of the documents set out above.    You should not use the NHS testing service to get a test in order to facilitate your travel to another country. You should arrange to take a private test.    Details of further exemptions from the requirements set out above are available here and include for example passengers transiting Croatia in under 12 hours.    If you are arriving in Croatia from countries other than the UK, Cyprus, Russia, South Africa, Brazil or Zanzibar and do not have one of the documents listed above, and are not subject to a specific exemption, you will be required to take a PCR test or rapid antigen test upon arrival in Croatia. You will need to self-isolate until the results of a negative test are received. Upon entry to Croatia, you will be handed instructions regarding the conditions for self isolation, which will include details about ending your self-isolation through a negative test. See more information about testing centres in Croatia.    If you travel to another country after receiving a negative PCR (72 hours validity) test or rapid antigen test (48 hours validity) in Croatia and return back to Croatia within less than 48 or 72 hours (for PCR) from the date of testing, you will not be required to provide a new test from the country you travelled to.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220125002528/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/croatia/entry-requirements

negative PCR test result not older than 72 hours from the moment of testing, or rapid antigen test result - RAT for SARS-CoV-2 that is included in the Common list of rapid antigen tests recognized by the Member States of the European Union, published by the European Commission, provided that the test result is not older than 48 hours from the moment of testing to the moment of arrival at the border crossing point  certificate not older than 365 days of receipt of two doses of vaccine used in EU Member States (Pfizer, Moderna, AstaZeneca, Gamaleya, Sinopharm) or vaccines approved by the World Health Organization for emergency use (Serum Institute of India - Covishield, Bharat Biotech - Covaxin, Sinovac - CoronaVac) or presentation of a certificate not older than 365 days of receipt one dose of vaccine received in one dose (Janssen / Johnson & Johnson) if 14 days have passed since receiving that one dose;  certificate showing that they have recovered from COVID-19 and have received one dose of vaccine used in EU Member States (Pfizer, Moderna, AstaZeneca, Gamaleya, Sinopharm within eight months from contracting the disease, provided that the vaccine was administered less than 356 days from their arrival at the border crossing point;  a positive PCR or rapid antigen test result, referred to in paragraph III, item 1, subitem 1 of the said Decision, confirming that the holder recovered from the SARS-CoV-2 virus infection, which was performed in the previous 365 days, and which is older than 11 days from the date of arrival at the border crossing point, or a certificate of recovery from COVID-19 issued by a physician;  or they will be imposed self-isolation upon arriving in the Republic of Croatia with a possibility of getting a PCR test or rapid antigen test for SARS-CoV-2 and if they cannot get tested, they have to self-isolate for a total of 10 days.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220129111606/https://mup.gov.hr/uzg-covid/english/286212

Mask-wearing. From November 20, masks must be worn again in shops, shopping malls, post offices, customer services, theatres, cinemas, in museums and sporting events. At indoor cultural and other events, gyms, swimming pools, spas, and catering shops, employees must wear a mask.   Hospitals have been banned from visiting.  Source: https://archive.vn/jJwx3   The 'EU Digital COVID Certificate' (EUDCC) is required to access some public spaces, such as bars and restaurants, museums, large events, and some means of public transport.   Source: https://archive.vn/XxhwO  Note: Employers may require the vaccine to be taken. For unvaccinated workers, the employer may set a 45-day deadline for taking the first vaccination. Employers who expect to be vaccinated must inform the employee by e-mail or on paper about the measure, the deadline and the possible legal consequences of not taking the vaccine. Vaccination is not expected to be given to a worker who is vaccinated and is contraindicated.   Vaccination is expected in the public sector, and mayors can decide on it.  Confirmatory third vaccination is also required for health care and some public administration workers.   Source: https://archive.vn/jJwx3

If there is no suspicion of infection, the passenger shall be accommodated in quarantine designated by the competent epidemiological authority for 10 days, or in official home quarantine. The passenger may be granted exemption, if they present two negative tests in conformity with professional medical regulations within 5 days, with at least 48 hours difference between the tests.   Source: https://archive.vn/b7O87

Non-essential travel to Hungary is only allowed to Hungarian citizens who hold an immunity card; non-Hungarian nationals who provide proof of vaccination; non-vaccinated - recovery from COVID-19 or a negative test result.    For vaccinated: required to be vaccinated to enter.  For non-vaccinated: Hungarian citizens without vaccination certificates, returning from abroad, are obliged to stay in home quarantine for 10 days from the date of entry. Passengers returning home may be exempted from quarantine if they provide a certificate containing the negative results of two SARS-CoV-2 molecular tests performed in Hungary at two different times, with at least 48 hours between them.     Source: https://archive.vn/XxhwO

The government is providing several significant subsidies.  Parents receive a family tax refund. In February 2022, parents raising a child will be refunded their income tax paid in 2021 up to the tax level of the average wage.  Retirees received a larger-than-ever pension premium  of HUF 80,000 in November and will receive a full refund  of their 13-month pension  in February 2022.  Wage increases will continue: from January 2022, the minimum wage will be HUF 200,000 and the guaranteed minimum wage will be HUF 260,000,  thus the minimum wage will be higher from 2022 onwards.  Young people under the age of  25 will not have to pay income tax  from January 2022.  The credit moratorium was extended until June 30, 2022. Those who are expecting and raising a child, retirees, and those in public employment can continue to take advantage of the opportunity, as can businesses and individuals whose incomes have fallen significantly from the previous year.  Source: https://archive.vn/3JHc5

No changes.  The government is providing several significant subsidies.  Parents receive a family tax refund. In February 2022, parents raising a child will be refunded their income tax paid in 2021 up to the tax level of the average wage.  Retirees received a larger-than-ever pension premium  of HUF 80,000 in November and will receive a full refund of their 13-month pension in February 2022.  Wage increases will continue: from January 2022, the minimum wage will be HUF 200,000 and the guaranteed minimum wage will be HUF 260,000,  thus the minimum wage will be higher from 2022 onwards.  Young people under the age of  25 will not have to pay income tax  from January 2022.  The credit moratorium was extended until June 30, 2022. Those who are expecting and raising a child, retirees, and those in public employment can continue to take advantage of the opportunity, as can businesses and individuals whose incomes have fallen significantly from the previous year.    Source: https://archive.vn/jJwx3

No contact tracing scheme officially announced.   Sources: https://archive.vn/3JHc5; https://archive.vn/b7O87.  But there is mobile contact tracing app - VirusRadar. Hungary launched VirusRadar mobile contact tracing application donated by Nextsense.   VirusRadar mobile application uses Nextsense Contact Tracing Technology for the detection of potentially exposed persons to Covid-19, implemented in StopKorona! mobile app. This mobile app for Apple iOS and Android implements the highest security standards, provides full control over personal data, and guarantees privacy protection. It uses the Bluetooth Low Energy protocol to detect anonymous, encrypted contacts. Nextsense, as a company with a high level of awareness for solidarity and support of the community, has made its technology for contact tracing for the exposure of Covid-19 available to authorities around the world as a donation.  Source: https://archive.vn/tlC8T

On 21 January 2022, the Government announced a plan for easing COVID-19 restrictions.    From 6am on 22 January 2022:    - Pubs and restaurants can return to normal opening times (no longer must close at 8pm)  - Nightclubs can reopen  - You no longer need a vaccination or recovery certificate to access hospitality or indoor activites  - Social distancing is no longer required in hospitality or other settings  - Restrictions on numbers attending indoor and outdoor events or activities no longer apply  - Limits on household visits no longer apply    https://web.archive.org/web/20220103083837/https://www.citizensinformation.ie/en/covid19/living_with_covid19_plan.html

On 21 January 2022, the Government announced a plan for easing COVID-19 restrictions.    From 6am on 22 January 2022:    - Pubs and restaurants can return to normal opening times (no longer must close at 8pm)  - Nightclubs can reopen  - You no longer need a vaccination or recovery certificate to access hospitality or indoor activites  - Social distancing is no longer required in hospitality or other settings  - Restrictions on numbers attending indoor and outdoor events or activities no longer apply  - Limits on household visits no longer apply    https://web.archive.org/web/20220103083837/https://www.citizensinformation.ie/en/covid19/living_with_covid19_plan.html
No changes in policy: https://archive.ph/gBq8W

Family and social gatherings  People should limit their contacts throughout the coming period to the greatest degree possible and visits to private homes should be kept to a maximum of 3 other households (that is, 4 households in total).    Hospitality  All restaurants, bars and cafes, excluding take away or delivery services, close at 8pm. This also applies to hotel restaurants and bars, except for overnight residents.    Strict social distancing is required in all bars and restaurants, including hotels (reverting to pre-22 October measures):    COVID pass required  table service only (no counter service)  1 metre between tables  maximum 6 adults per table (maximum 15 persons when including children aged 12 and younger)  no multiple table bookings and no intermingling  masks when not seated at table  Nightclubs are closed.    You may be asked for contact tracing data (for example: name, contact number).    Indoor events  No indoor events, including entertainment, cultural, community and sporting events, will take place after 8pm. In relation to events happening earlier in the day, attendance should be limited to 50% of venue capacity or 1,000 attendees, whichever is the lower. This includes cinemas. This does not affect religious, educational or normal workplace business activity and business events (for example: conferences, trade fairs).    You may be asked for contact tracing data (for example: name, contact number).    Wedding receptions can take place with a capacity limit of 100 guests and continue after 8pm. Midnight closing time still applies.    Religious services  Religious services can proceed without capacity limits but with all other protective measures remaining in place.    Outdoor events  Attendance at outdoor events, including entertainment, cultural, community and sporting events, should be limited to 50% of venue capacity or 5,000 attendees, whichever is the lower.    Group activities  Organisers of indoor and outdoor group activities should ensure that appropriate protective measures are in place, and where indoor groups have a mix of vaccinated and unvaccinated people indoors, pods of 6 should apply.    For children under 18, the âpod of 6â system can be adjusted to allow for indoor games and competition activities only, with all other protective measures remaining in place.    The âpod of 6â system should be retained for all other settings such as training activities and games as part of training. Fixed capacity limits will not apply to these indoor and outdoor group activities.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220121175253/https://www.gov.ie/en/publication/3361b-public-health-updates/

vaccinated or recovered travellers into Ireland are required to present evidence of a valid EU Digital COVID Certificate (DCC) or other acceptable proof of vaccination/previous COVID-19 infection prior to travel  travellers that are not vaccinated or recovered are required to present evidence of a negative ('not detected') RT-PCR test carried out no more than 72 hours before their arrival into Ireland, unless exempt  Any individual that develops COVID-19 symptoms should follow the HSE guidance in relation to isolation and undertake antigen or RT-PCR testing as appropriate.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220121175253/https://www.gov.ie/en/publication/3361b-public-health-updates/

You must complete a Passenger Locator Form online before you arrive in Ireland and tell the authorities if your residence details change within 14 days. This is set out in the SI 45 of 2021 (pdf), as amended, which applies until 6 February 2022. Failure to do this is an offence.    Some arrivals to Ireland are required to show proof of RT-PCR pre-departure testing.    Exemptions from pre-departure testing are set out in Statutory Instrument 135 of 2021 (pdf), as amended, which apply until 9 February 2022.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220128230204/https://www.citizensinformation.ie/en/health/covid19/public_health_measures_for_covid19.html

Following a recommendation of the European Union Commission, Ireland has announced that from February 1, travellers vaccinated with Novavax can enter the country under the same travel rules as those vaccinated with Pfizer, Moderna, Janssen, and AstraZeneca, as the vaccine has recently been approved for use in the EU  by the European Medicines Agency (EMA).    https://web.archive.org/web/20220202162132/https://www.schengenvisainfo.com/news/new-travel-rules-enter-into-force-today-in-ireland/

A, B, C    Get your booster vaccine if you are eligible â being vaccinated offers good protection against severe illness and hospitalisation and lowers the risk to you and others. 16/01/22  Current restrictions on school activities  The regulation issued by the Minister of Health on the restriction of school activities due to stricter infection prevention measures is effective until 2 February 2022.    Preschools and day-care parents  Maximum number of employees in each area: 20.  Minimum distance between employees: 2 metres.  Use of masks by employees: Where a 2-metre distance limit between employees is not possible. There is no mask obligation in communication with preschool children.  Transfer of employees between groups: Allowed.  Maximum number of children in each area: 50.  Minimum distance between children: None.  Use of face masks by children: None.  Outside area: no limits to the number of people.    Events related to the work or social activities of preschools, such as plays and concerts, may not be attended by anyone other than students and teachers.      Primary schools and after-school activities  Grades 1 to 10    Maximum number of employees in an area: 20.  Minimum distance between employees: 2 metres.  Use of masks by employees: Where a 2-metre distance limit between employees and towards students is not possible.  Transfer of employees and students between groups: Allowed.  Maximum number of children in each area: 50.  Minimum distance between children: 1 metre in classrooms.  Use of face masks by children: None.  Physical education and school swimming lessons: Allowed.  Maximum number of students in cafeteria: 50.  Shared areas (entrances, foyers, lavatories and hallways): Restrictions on the number of persons present may be waived if employees use face masks.  Outdoor area: No restrictions, but efforts should be made to limit the number of students in each outdoor area unless it impedes outdoor activities.    The restrictions on the number of people do not apply on the school bus.    Events related to the work or social activities of primary schools, such as lectures, reading competitions, etc., may not be attended by anyone other than students and teachers.    After-school activities  The same restrictions apply as apply to preschools and primary schools. One individual is allowed to accompany a child of a preschool age in after-school activities.    Events related to the work or social activities of primary schools, such as plays and concerts, lectures, reading competitions, etc., may not be attended by anyone other than students and teachers.    Mixing between groups: Allowed.    Music schools  All music lessons for children at a preschool and primary school age is permitted with the same restrictions as apply to their school activities.  Maximum number of employees in an area: 20.  Minimum distance between individuals: 2 metres.  Use of face masks: Students born in 2005 and earlier, as well as employees, should wear masks if social distancing rules cannot be followed, if possible.  Transfer of employees between areas: Allowed.  Maximum number of students in an area: 50.  Studentsâ social distancing rules: Follow the rules for each school level.    Events related to the work or social activities of music schools, such as concerts, may not be attended by anyone other than students and teachers.    Upper secondary schools  Maximum number of employees and students in an area: 50.  Maximum number of employees in an area: 20.  Minimum distance between individuals: 2 metres.  Use of face masks: Where a 2-metre distance is not possible.  In classrooms, it is permitted to have a distance of 1 metre between students, but then the use of a face mask is required.  Transfer of employees and students between groups: Allowed.  Physical education: Allowed with the same restrictions as other teaching measures.  Maximum number of students in cafeteria: 50.  Shared areas (entrances, foyers, lavatories and hallways): Restrictions on the number of persons present may be waived if employees use face masks.    In situations where it is not possible to enforce social distancing, such as in practical teaching, art teaching and teaching students in vocational training, students and teachers must wear a face mask.  Students may stay in a dormitory.  Events not related to teaching or education are not to be conducted on the school premises.  Events related to work or social activities in upper secondary school are subject to the provisions on performing arts in the regulation on the restrictions on gatherings due to a pandemic.    Universities  Maximum number of employees and students per room: 50.  Maximum number of employees in an area: 20.  Minimum distance between individuals: 2 metres.  Use of face masks: Where a 2-metre distance is not possible.  In classrooms, it is permitted to have a distance of 1 metre between students, but then the use of a mask is required.  Transfer between groups: Allowed.  Physical education: Allowed with the same restrictions as other teaching measures.  Maximum number of students in cafeteria: 50.  Shared areas (entrances, foyers, lavatories and hallways): Restrictions on the number of persons present may be waived if employees use face masks.  In situations where it is not possible to enforce social distancing, such as in practical teaching, art teaching and clinical studies, school work is permitted as long as infection prevention measures are followed and on the condition that students and teachers wear a face mask.    Other events not related to teaching or education are not to be conducted on the school premises.  This provision does not prevent students from staying in dormitories.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220116174134/https://www.covid.is/sub-categories/effective-restrictions
23/01/22    No changes detected   https://web.archive.org/web/20220123191320/https://www.covid.is/sub-categories/effective-restrictions

16/01/22    Managers are responsible for informing their employees of the workplaceâs response plan and what rules apply to its operation while the COVID-19 precautionary measures remain in effect. The need for meetings must be assessed, particularly if there are many attendees. Such meetings should preferably be held using teleconferencing equipment whenever possible. This also applies to meetings within the company if possible. Care must be taken as regards employee travel overseas. Then ecessity of travel must be assessed each time, and employees should avoid such travel unless it is unavoidable.    It is important that managers encourage their employees to take care of their health and to stay at home if they experience any illness. Employees with underlying illnesses are particularly at risk from the virus and should, therefore, consult with their superior as to the possibility of working from home as much as possible if that is an option.  https://web.archive.org/web/20220110105656/https://www.covid.is/sub-categories/workplaces

16/01/22  Up to 50 people may attend an event if the following criteria is met:    1) All guests are seated and not facing each other  2) 1 meter social distancing between guests  3) All attendees were a mask.  4) Alcoholic beverages are not sold before, during or after event.  5) Guests are asked to remain seated even if an interval is necessary, if at all possible.  Social distancing rules  At all workplaces and when performing other professional activities, individuals who are unrelated must keep a distance of 2 metre from each other.    At gatherings where all guest are seated 1 metre must be kept between guests, and a face mask must be worn.  Children born in 2016 and later are excempt from social distancing rules.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220116174134/https://www.covid.is/sub-categories/effective-restrictions

Here you can read more regarding travel restrictions to Iceland as a result of COVID-19.    This quick guide to COVID-19 border measures will help you find out what general rules apply when entering Iceland. The information provided here is for guidance only. A final decision on entry is in all cases made at the border.    Rules at the border  With vaccination certificate or a certificate of previous infection  Travelers without a vaccination certificate or a certificate of previous infection  Transit passengers    Trips abroad  Residents of Iceland are advised not to travel to risk areas without vaccination. All countries are currently defined as risk areas due to COVID-19.  https://web.archive.org/web/20220110110711/https://www.covid.is/sub-categories/travel-to-and-within-iceland

16/01/22  Three types of COVID-tests are in use. PCR-tests are used by the health care system to test people with COVID-19 symptoms, and when people might be infected. Rapid antigen tests are also used in the health care system and by certified test centers, both before events, but also at the beginning and end of special precaution. Self-tests people can buy in stores are not deemed reliable. A postitive result should always be confirmed with a PCR test.    Information on centres for COVID-19 PCR or rapid antigen tests  PCR-test - Symptom testing:  If you have symptoms or suspect you have an infection, you should be tested even if you have been vaccinated.  Stay at home and register immediately for testing on My Page at Heilsuvera. If you do not have an electronic ID, you can contact, by telephone, your local healthcare centre, LÃ¦knavaktin 1700 (the on-call medical hotline) or the Heilsuvera online chat. If you have not been in contact with someone infected you are not obliged to islolate until a negative test result is obtained. However it is important to be mindful of social distancing and handwashing and to use a mask if it is nessessary to be around others. You should not, under any circumstances, visit your healthcare centre, the LSH Emergency Unit or LÃ¦knavaktin if you have symptoms, without calling first and receiving advice.  PCR-tests are also used for shortened quarantine. See below.  The symptoms may seem minor but it is still important to be tested, no matter how small they seem.  Symptom testing is always free of charge, for tourists as well.  Rapid antigen test - testing for asymptomatic people  Rapid antigen tests are used to screen for COVID-19 virus with asymptomatic people. If you suspect you have an infection, you should have a PCR-test.  Self-tests  Self-tests are not deemed reliable. If you test positive on a self-test, you should go for a PCR test (free) immediatly and follow the rules on isolation until your results are ready.  https://web.archive.org/web/20220116183316/https://www.covid.is/sub-categories/testing-due-to-symptoms

travel restrictions have ceased for South Africa.  For most countries it is mandatory to exhibit a negative test (antigen or PCR) in conjunction with a Super Green Pass (vaccinated or recovered).  https://web.archive.org/web/20220121174357/https://www.salute.gov.it/portale/nuovocoronavirus/dettaglioContenutiNuovoCoronavirus.jsp?lingua=italiano&id=5411&area=nuovoCoronavirus&menu=vuoto

travel restrictions have ceased for South Africa.  For most countries it is mandatory to exhibit a negative test (antigen or PCR) in conjunction with a Super Green Pass (vaccinated or recovered) if this is not done people will have to self-quarantine.  https://web.archive.org/web/20220121174357/https://www.salute.gov.it/portale/nuovocoronavirus/dettaglioContenutiNuovoCoronavirus.jsp?lingua=italiano&id=5411&area=nuovoCoronavirus&menu=vuoto

For most countries, except for European countries, it is mandatory to exhibit a negative test (antigen or PCR) in conjunction with a Super Green Pass (vaccinated or recovered), if this is not done people will only be admitted if they have residency or working permits, and will therefore have to self-quarantine. For tourism and without a proof of vaccination, it won't be possible to enter Italy from countries in the D & E list.  https://web.archive.org/web/20220204150250/https://www.salute.gov.it/portale/nuovocoronavirus/dettaglioContenutiNuovoCoronavirus.jsp?lingua=italiano&id=5411&area=nuovoCoronavirus&menu=vuoto&tab=5

For tourism and without a proof of vaccination, it won't be possible to enter Italy from countries in the D & E list.  https://web.archive.org/web/20220211173255/https://www.salute.gov.it/portale/nuovocoronavirus/dettaglioContenutiNuovoCoronavirus.jsp?lingua=italiano&id=5411&area=nuovoCoronavirus&menu=vuoto

Although the methodology to perform contact tracing has not changed (all close contacts need to be tested or self-quarantine if they don't want to be tested), since the end of December contact tracing has been struggling to trace all close contacts of positives. With very high positive numbers (around 219000 on January 6th) and over a million tests performed most days, the tracing methodology is struggling to function and test everyone: long queues have been forming to get tested as well as long delays to get the results.  It seems the tracing methodology is still comprehensive though so marking as such  https://web.archive.org/web/20211228213909/https://gazzettadelsud.it/articoli/cronaca/2021/12/28/covid-tracciamento-dei-contatti-e-file-per-i-tamponi-il-sistema-e-andato-in-tilt-0f087917-40ef-4c83-8530-840469ae6f48/   https://web.archive.org/web/20220106175030/https://www.offida.info/covid-record-di-contagi-in-italia-e-nelle-marche/

A wide variety of businesses â including gyms and fitness centers, pools, beaches, cultural facilities, museums, exhibits, entertainment centers, religious facilities, some movie theaters, food courts, and recreational facilities â are open, subject to participation in Ashyq, to increasing restrictions on hours of operations, and to capacity limitations due to the detection of the omicron variant in Kazakhstan. However, some regional and local governments periodically impose restrictions in response to increases in the infection rate.    Ashyq Application:  Businesses that would otherwise be closed or subject to opening and/or occupancy restrictions may open under less restrictive conditions by participating in âAshyq,â an application that displays a color-coded risk status for each visitor based on information in Ministry of Health COVID-19 infection, PCR test, and vaccination databases.  https://web.archive.org/web/20220106223333/https://kz.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/
"All large events and family gatherings are prohibited."   Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20220108012336/https://kz.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

All large events and family gatherings are prohibited. Individual and group outdoor fitness activities are permitted, and people may walk in parks and other public spaces in groups of three or less.  https://web.archive.org/web/20220106223333/https://kz.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

Is public transportation operating?  Yes  https://web.archive.org/web/20220106223333/https://kz.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/    Public transport operates from 06:00-23:00 Monday-Saturday and is suspended on Sundays  https://web.archive.org/web/20220102065005/https://www.garda.com/crisis24/news-alerts/551076/kazakhstan-authorities-announce-tightening-of-international-entry-restrictions-due-to-omicron-covid-19-variant-from-dec-3-update-50

Nationwide, authorities require residents to obtain a government-provided QR code via the Ashyq mobile application to visit government offices and certain public spaces, including leisure facilities, cultural venues, and entertainment establishments. Ashyq codes are also required to gain entry to international airports in Almaty and Nur-Sultan. Residents will have their app scanned at each establishment; each QR code scan will reveal a resident's color-coded risk rating:    Red - movement restricted to self-isolation regime    Yellow - movement partially restricted; essential trips to nearest pharmacy and grocery store permitted    Blue - no specific restrictions    Green - no specific restrictions, and the user has a negative result from a COVID-19 PCR test.
No changes found

Kazakhstan will tighten international entry restrictions from Dec. 3 over concerns regarding the recently identified Omicron variant of COVID-19. From this date, nonresident foreign nationals from the following countries are prohibited from entry: South Africa, Botswana, Lesotho, Namibia, Zimbabwe, Mozambique, Madagascar, eSwatini, Malawi, Tanzania, and Hong Kong. Additionally, travelers from countries that have declared the presence of the Omicron variant must - regardless of vaccination status - present a negative PCR test and self-isolate for seven days on arrival; these countries currently include Australia, Belgium, the UK, Czech Republic, Germany, Egypt, Israel, Italy, Canada, and the Netherlands.    Other international entry restrictions remain in effect. Visa-free travel remains suspended. However, flights with several countries have resumed, including Belarus, Egypt, Germany, South Korea, Kyrgyzstan, the Netherlands, Russia, Turkey, Ukraine, the UAE, and Uzbekistan, though capacity is likely to be limited. Some routes may also be suspended in the wake of the new entry restrictions.    As of Nov. 30, all international arrivals must provide a vaccination certificate or evidence of a negative COVID-19 test taken no more than 72 hours before entry into Kazakhstan.   https://web.archive.org/web/20220102065005/https://www.garda.com/crisis24/news-alerts/551076/kazakhstan-authorities-announce-tightening-of-international-entry-restrictions-due-to-omicron-covid-19-variant-from-dec-3-update-50
A government COVID app is in wide use.  https://web.archive.org/web/20211120144442/https://kz.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

No manual contact tracing.     However the Ashyq app is available:    "The mobile application "Ashyq" enables through the use of a QR code and integration with the general database of the Ministry of Health of the Republic of Kazakhstan, to determine the status of a visitor: whether he is currently a carrier of the virus or not.    For the businesses, this makes it possible to continue their activities during the period of quarantine measures, as well as minimizes the risks of the spread of Covid-19 and reduces the number of contacts leading to infection.    The use of the application for both entrepreneurs and citizens is free.    Today, every person who becomes ill with COVID-19 in any form (symptomatic or asymptomatic) undertakes to comply with the home quarantine regime and assures them with a personal signature on the receipt. However, we often come across facts of violation of the self-isolation regime."    Archived web link: https://web.archive.org/web/20211105195803/https://egov.kz/cms/en/articles/prilozhenie-ashyq

Masks Required: The Chief Sanitary Doctor of Kazakhstan has mandated that masks be worn nationwide in public settings, including both indoor and outdoor spaces and on public transportation. Failure to comply with this measure could result in administrative penalty.   Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20211120144442/https://kz.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

Vaccines: Sputnik V, QazVac, CoronaVac and Sinopharm.    Quote: "Has the government of Kazakhstan approved a COVID-19 vaccine for use?  Yes  Are vaccines available in Kazakhstan for U.S. citizens to receive?  Yes, for permanent residents (see below).  Which vaccines are available in Kazakhstan? Sputnik V, QazVac, CoronaVac and Sinopharm.  On April 7, 2021, the Minister of Health announced in a press briefing that foreigners who live and work in Kazakhstan and have permanent residence cards may receive COVID-19 vaccination free of charge just like Kazakhstani citizens.  Currently, the only record of this announcement is in media reporting.  The Ministry of Health of Kazakhstan initiated a multi-stage vaccination program on February 1, 2021"  Archive Link  https://web.archive.org/web/20211123093223/https://kz.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

No changes. https://archive.ph/WqhO3

For gatherings of up to 10 people, there are no restrictions or health measures to be observed.  For gatherings of 11 to 20 people (inclusive), masks and a physical distance of 2 metres between people are mandatory, or the CovidCheck (2G+) system applies.   Gatherings of between 21 and 200 people (inclusive) are subject to the CovidCheck 2G+ system, or the requirement to wear a mask and be seated at a minimum distance of 2 metres. CovidCheck 2G+ means that each person over 12 years and 2 months of age must present a vaccination or recovery certificate. They must also undergo a test exempt vaccination within the last 180 days, booster vaccination or recovery certificate.   Gatherings of more than 200 people are prohibited, unless they are subject to a health protocol accepted in advance by the Health Directorate, which determines the health measures to be observed.   https://archive.ph/lgq7X

There is a comprehensive public health campaign, including helpline, websites, covid-passes etc.   The Covid19 call centre (92 05 55 00) is available seven days a week from 8 am to 8 pm. The Government has set up a National Screening Center. It is located on the ground floor of the Rainier III Auditorium.    The aim is to regulate and co-ordinate PCR testing in order to optimise the time taken to obtain results.    This screening center welcomes any Monegasque, Monegasque resident or insured in Monaco or any student educated in Monaco, with the obligation to make an appointment in advance by calling the call center

The following are considered to be contact persons:    Anyone who has touched the person infected with COVID-19 or been within less than 1,5 metres of them for more than 15 minutes  Anyone who has spoken to the person infected with COVID-19  Anyone who has cleaned biological fluids from the person infected with COVID-19 without protection  Close friends  Anyone living in the same home or visiting the same dormitory as the person infected with COVID-19  Contact persons are not considered to be infected and the probability that they will infect others is very low, however:    They will be self-isolating at home for 14 days  They will take their temperature twice a day  They will be subject to medical monitoring  They may undergo biological testing during this period  If a contact person develops COVID-19 (fever, symptoms or positive test), they become a confirmed case and the public health investigation is expanded to search for contact persons.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210329164735/https://covid19.mc/en/on-vous-repond/
It is compulsory to wear a mask both indoors and outdoors at all times throughout the Principality. https://web.archive.org/web/20211229002011/https://covid19.mc/en/thematiques/outings-and-purchases/

Vaccination is done on a voluntary basis.    Currently, Monegasques and residents aged 12 and over can have the vaccine. Furthermore, from Monday 28 June, the vaccination will be extended to all public sector staff.    For the vaccination of Monegasques or residents who are minors, parents must complete the "Authorisation for the vaccination of a minor against COVID-19,"    https://web.archive.org/web/20210901104853/https://covid19.mc/en/fight-against-coronavirus/vaccination/

Moldovan authorities established new public health measures to limit the spread of COVID-19 infection at all public events and gatherings, both indoor and outdoor.  Anyone over the age of 18 eating in a restaurant or cafÃ© or attending any show, concert, festival, theater, cinema, concert hall, nightclub, dance floor, etc., must present one of the following documents: 1) a negative PCR COVID-19 test (taken in the last 72 hours) or an antigen test (taken in the last 48 hours); 2) a COVID-19 vaccine certificate (valid 14 days after the second dose); 3) a medical certificate attesting the person had COVID-19 in the previous 6 months; 4) a COVID-19 antibodies certificate valid for 90 days from the exam date. In addition, the government has extended the state of emergency until March 15th.  https://web.archive.org/web/20220114124622/https://msmps.gov.md/comunicare/comunicate/cnesp-a-decis-prelungirea-starii-de-urgenta-in-sanatate-publica/  https://web.archive.org/web/20220125001334/https://md.usembassy.gov/u-s-citizen-services/covid-19-information/

It is forbidden to organize private events (weddings, baptisms, memorial meals, festive meals). The activity of leisure areas and amusement parks is stopped, as well as the activities inside the nightclubs and dance floors. - The activities inside the theaters, cinemas and concert halls will take place at a capacity of 50% of the number of seats inside, with the obligation that all visitors present at the entrance the COVID certificate.    https://archive.ph/ZIURe

Private events (festive meals, corporate parties, weddings, baptisms) with 25 or more participants will still be allowed only with their presentation of the COVID-19 certificate, in the green and yellow alert thresholds.   In the orange and red alert thresholds, the rules for private events do not change. Thus, in the orange threshold they are allowed only with the presentation by the participants of the COVID-19 certificate, and in the red alert threshold they remain forbidden.  https://web.archive.org/web/20220114124622/https://msmps.gov.md/comunicare/comunicate/cnesp-a-decis-prelungirea-starii-de-urgenta-in-sanatate-publica/

No entry bans from any country. The following rules applied to over 50 countries until January 17th and applies to all countries since then: Moldova requires anyone entering the country present one of the following:  1) a COVID-19 vaccine certificate (valid 14 days after the second dose); 2) a negative PCR COVID-19 test (taken in the last 72 hours) or an antigen test (taken in the last 48 hours); 3) a medical certificate attesting the person had COVID-19 in the previous 6 months; or 4) a COVID-19 antibodies certificate valid for 90 days from the exam date.  Any COVID-19 antibodies certificate or evidence of vaccination must be in Romanian, English, French, German, Italian, or Russian language.  Moldovan Border Police accept all types of vaccination with appropriate documentation.  Absent one of the documents listed above, a traveler will have to self-isolate for 14 days.  Self-isolation may be discontinued after 7 days if a COVID-19 PCR test or a rapid SARS-CoV-2 Ag test is performed, and the result is negative based on a confirmative document.  If you are subject to self-isolation and depart Moldova, you could be fined for violating self-isolation.  Anyone required to self-isolate should complete an online epidemiological card 3 days before arriving in Moldova.  https://web.archive.org/web/20220125001334/https://md.usembassy.gov/u-s-citizen-services/covid-19-information/  https://web.archive.org/web/20220107182222/https://msmps.gov.md/comunicare/lista-statelor-cu-risc-epidemiologic-sporit-de-transmitere-a-infectiei-covid-l9-2/

No changes in policy.  Key Policy Responses as of July 1, 2021. A comprehensive fiscal package has been adopted as per two 2020 State Budget Amendments, following several targeted fiscal measures to support businesses and vulnerable households, such as expanding unemployment benefits and strengthening existing targeted social assistance, tax relief for sectors affected by state-imposed restrictions, delaying tax payment deadlines to mid-2020, suspending tax audits and other controls, and increasing state budget allocations to the budget emergency and health funds and to a mortgage guarantee program. The approved 2021 Budget envisages more support to the health sector, and farmers support.  https://web.archive.org/web/20220124235307/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19

"Daycare centres for children aged 0 to 4 are open.  From Monday 20 December 2021 to Sunday 9 January 2022 primary schools and schools for special education will be closed. Out-of-school care centres (BSO) will also be closed. Primary schools, schools for special education and out-of-school care centres will reopen on 10 January 2022.  Secondary schools and special secondary schools will be closed from Monday 20 December 2021 to Sunday 9 January 2022. These schools will reopen on 10 January 2022.  Schools for secondary vocational education (MBO) will be closed from Monday 20 December 2021 to Sunday 9 January 2022. These schools will offer remote learning from 10 January 2022.  Higher education institutions (HBO and universities) will be closed from Monday 20 December 2021 to Sunday 9 January 2022. They will offer remote learning from 10 January 2022."  https://archive.fo/LPiIo
As of 10 January primary schools re-opened and higher education reopened on the 14th of Janaury  https://archive.fo/NKr6g  https://archive.fo/X9iJ6

"Pupils and staff with symptoms, including mild cold symptoms, must stay at home and get tested by the municipal health service (GGD) or do a self-test.   Staff at primary and secondary schools and pupils in secondary education must wear a face mask while moving around the building. Children in primary years 6, 7 and 8 are strongly advised to wear a face mask while moving around the building. Face masks may be taken off in the classroom. Children under 18 no longer have to self-quarantine if someone they live with or have been in close contact with has coronavirus. This also applies to secondary school pupils aged 18 and over, and to students under 18 in secondary vocational education (MBO) and higher education (HBO and universities).  Schools must take measures to prevent transmission of the virus, like one-way corridors, staggered breaks and limiting contacts between pupils in different classes. Children who are able to go to and from school on their own should do so.  All teaching staff at schools, pupils at secondary schools and pupils in primary years 6, 7 and 8 should do a self-test at home twice a week as a precaution, if necessary with the help of a parent or guardian. This also applies to staff and pupils who have been vaccinated or have received their booster vaccination. If the result of the self-test is positive, the pupil or staff member must get tested by the GGD. If the result of the self-test is negative, they can return to school. The basic rules also still apply."  https://archive.fo/BVoeW
No policy change  https://archive.fo/NKr6g

"Everyone aged 13 and over must show a coronavirus entry pass at locations where this is mandatory, such as restaurants, bars, theatres and music venues, museums, cinemas, zoos, amusement parks, saunas and casinos. Night clubs remain closed for everyone  https://archive.fo/rVYZZ    Covid pass required to gain access to:  "indoor and outdoor areas at establishments serving food and drinks (except for takeaway);  sports clubhouses (if you are aged 18 or over);  indoor and outdoor areas at:  amusement parks and zoos;  play and gaming venues such as casinos, indoor playgrounds and arcades;  saunas, spas and tanning salons;  recreational transport such as tour boats and party buses;  indoor and outdoor events with assigned seating, such as celebrations, performances and film screenings;  events with a continuous flow of people such as funfairs and street markets;  business events, such as trade shows and conferences;  as a spectator:  professional sports matches and competitions;  amateur sport matches and competition indoors (if you are aged 18 or over);  indoor sports venues, including gyms and swimming pools (if you are aged 18 or over);  cultural venues such as cinemas, theatres, concert halls and museums;  artistic and cultural activities, such as music and painting lessons and singing, dance and theatre rehearsals (if you are aged 18 or over). "  https://archive.fo/ASJef#selection-163.0-265.141

"Everyone aged 13 and over must show a coronavirus entry pass at locations where this is mandatory, such as restaurants, bars, theatres and music venues, museums, cinemas, zoos, amusement parks, saunas and casinos. At sports facilities, a coronavirus entry pass is required for people aged 18 and over."  https://archive.fo/kGpAt

"Where to show a coronavirus entry pass  You must show a coronavirus entry pass to gain admission to:    Hospitality venues, such as bars and restaurants (indoors and outdoors). This also includes department store cafÃ©s, hotel restaurants and sports clubhouses, and any outdoor seating areas at these establishments. At sports clubhouses, only people aged 18 and over have to show a coronavirus entry pass.   An establishment that serves food and drink may also host an activity for which a coronavirus entry pass is not required. If that activity is held in a separate space, coronavirus entry passes do not need to be shown.   Amusement parks, zoos, casinos, play and gaming venues (such as indoor playgrounds), saunas, spas, tanning salons and recreational transportation.   Locations with a continuous flow of visitors in sectors where coronavirus entry passes are mandatory (hospitality, sports, art and culture, and events). This includes museums and historic buildings.  Events with a continuous flow of visitors and no assigned seating, such as funfairs.  Events with assigned seating, venues for parties, performances and screenings.   Business events, such as trade fairs and conferences.   Professionals sports matches and competitions, indoors and outdoors, for spectators aged 13 and over.   Indoor sports facilities such as gyms, sports halls and swimming pools, for people aged 18 and over wishing to use these facilities for lessons, training, recreational sport and competitions and matches. This also applies to people wishing to use any indoor facilities, such as changing rooms, at a venue for outdoor sports.   Cultural venues, such as theatres, concert halls and cinemas.   Artistic and cultural activities, such as music and painting lessons, and singing, dance and theatre rehearsals, for participants aged 18 and over. "  https://archive.fo/BVoeW
